rating_criteria.description: Shoulder ratings differ based on whether the condition affects the MAJOR (dominant) or MINOR (non-dominant) arm

major_arm.criteria: Arm limited to shoulder level (90 degrees)
Arm limited to midway between side and shoulder level (45 degrees)
Arm limited to 25 degrees from side

minor_arm.criteria: Arm limited to shoulder level (90 degrees)
Arm limited to midway between side and shoulder level (45 degrees)
Arm limited to 25 degrees from side

ankylosis_scapulohumeral.description: Ankylosis of scapulohumeral articulation (scapula and humerus move as one piece)

major_arm.criteria: Favorable (abduction to 60 degrees, can reach mouth and head)
Unfavorable (abduction limited to 25 degrees from side)

minor_arm.criteria: Favorable (abduction to 60 degrees, can reach mouth and head)
Unfavorable (abduction limited to 25 degrees from side)

major_arm.criteria: Malunion with moderate deformity OR recurrent dislocation at scapulohumeral joint with infrequent episodes and guarding of movement only at shoulder level
Malunion with marked deformity OR recurrent dislocation with frequent episodes and guarding of all arm movements
Loss of head of humerus (flail shoulder)

minor_arm.criteria: Malunion with moderate or marked deformity OR recurrent dislocation with infrequent or frequent episodes
Loss of head of humerus (flail shoulder)

major_arm.criteria: Malunion OR nonunion without loose movement
Nonunion with loose movement OR dislocation

minor_arm.criteria: Malunion OR nonunion without loose movement
Nonunion with loose movement OR dislocation

major_arm.criteria: For 1 year following implantation of prosthesis
With chronic residuals consisting of severe painful motion or weakness
With intermediate degrees of residual weakness, pain, or limitation of motion (minimum rating)

minor_arm.criteria: For 1 year following implantation of prosthesis
With chronic residuals consisting of severe painful motion or weakness
With intermediate degrees of residual weakness, pain, or limitation of motion (minimum rating)

exam_sections: Range of Motion (ROM) and Functional Limitation
Shoulder Instability, Dislocation or Labral Pathology
Clavicle, Scapula, AC Joint and Sternoclavicular Joint Conditions
Conditions or Impairments of the Humerus

dominant_hand_impact.description: Ratings are HIGHER for major (dominant) arm conditions
dominant_hand_impact.note: Ambidextrous veterans - the affected arm is considered the major arm
dominant_hand_impact.example: Arm limited to 25 degrees: Major arm = 40%, Minor arm = 30%

tips_for_veterans: CONFIRM which is your dominant hand at the start of exam
Describe your WORST days, not average days
Report ALL symptoms: pain, weakness, instability, grinding/popping
Mention if shoulder dislocates or feels like it will
Describe activities you can no longer do (reaching overhead, lifting)
If you have rotator cuff issues, describe how they affect function
Document any history of shoulder dislocations
Report sleep problems due to shoulder pain
Mention if you cannot raise arm above shoulder level
Don't push through pain during ROM testing
Ask examiner to test both active AND passive motion
common_mistakes: Forgetting to mention instability or dislocation episodes
Not describing impact on overhead activities
Failing to mention rotator cuff symptoms
Not documenting how condition affects work and daily life
important_notes: Dominant vs non-dominant arm significantly affects rating percentage
ROM measurements must include flexion, abduction, and rotation
Painful motion warrants consideration of functional loss
Instability/dislocation may warrant separate rating from arthritis
Examiner must estimate ROM during flare-ups
Rotator cuff conditions are very common in veterans
